Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Advanced 3D Simulation Software for Electromagnetic Telemetry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that the project facilitate the design and operation of electromagnetic telemetry for underground wireless communication in oilfield measurement-while-drilling (MWD) and logging-while-drilling (LWD). The performance of an electromagnetic telemetry system is heavily dependent on electrical properties of the underground formation, as well as the deployment of downhole and surface antennas. Rigorous electromagnetic full wave simulations are critical in design, development, and deployment of an electromagnetic telemetry system for a drilling job. The modeling software package will potentially be the first product on the market with the capability of providing efficient 3D simulations of electromagnetic telemetry systems in complicated underground environments. Besides the oil and gas industry, electromagnetic telemetry can also be used in other important areas such as CO2 sequestration, deep borehole disposal of nuclear waste, and geothermal energy exploration.

This I-Corps project explores the market potential of a 3D electromagnetic telemetry modeling tool for the oil and gas industry and other areas involving drilling activities. A realistic electromagnetic telemetry system is an extremely multiscale structure, and rigorously modeling such a system is beyond the capabilities of available commercial electromagnetic simulation tools. The proposed product is based on the recent advancement of computational electromagnetics algorithms using 3D integral equations with a novel coated thin wire model to simulate the metallic drill string and borehole environment in layered formation. The product as a modeling software can be several orders more accurate than existing commercial simulation tools for the analysis of electromagnetic telemetry systems. The goal of this I-Corps team is to investigate the market potential of this technology and related product in the oilfield and other relevant applicable areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps project supports the Well Logging Laboratory at the University of Houston to explore the feasibility of commercializing the fast modeling algorithm and software for electromagnetic telemetry developed in the lab to the oilfield service industry. The project provided essential entrepreneurship training to the participating faculty members and student. A very valuable outcome of the project is the experience and findings the team obtained from conducting 170+ interviews (103 during the 6-week I-Corps Cohort, 70+ afterwards at industrial conferences and exhibitions) with professionals in the oilfield service and geosciences areas. Through the interactions with professionals the research lab has greatly enhanced the understandings of oilfield service business, and expanded its networking and collaborations with the oil and gas exploration industry.


This NSF I-Corps project has generated many good outcomes: 1) The participating student obtained his PhD degree in Fall 2019 and joined a startup geophysical/petrophysical consulting firm. The training ths student received from I-Corps helps him a lot on his job responsibility focused on development and commercialization of well logging data analysis software at the company. 2) The UH research lab has built extension connections with various oil and gas operators and oilfield service companies. The research work on fast modeling of electromagnetic telemetry has been recognized by industry and research community with several invited talks to a variety of communities (e.g. Society of HPC Professionals) and companies (e.g. Schlumberger, Shell, Chevron). 3) The UH research lab was awarded a Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project on fast modeling of electromagnetic telemetry (teaming up with a small high-tech company based in the Houston area) in early 2020. The market studies based on 170+ interviews of potential customers greatly strengthened the commercialization plan in the proposal.


Last Modified: 02/28/2020
Modified by: Jiefu Chen
